title: 106_hr4183
content: The "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" is introduced to amend the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to establish Next-Generation Technology Innovation Awards for schools. The purpose of this part is to expand knowledge about advanced technology in education, address national questions, and develop innovative teaching models for widespread adoption. The Secretary is authorized to award grants for this program. The Secretary is authorized to award grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements for a period of up to 5 years through the Office of Educational Technology to eligible applicants to implement advanced technology in education aligned with academic standards. "Eligibility for grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements for implementing advanced technology in education aligned with academic standards is outlined in SEC. 3212." To be eligible for an award under this part, a consortium must include a State or local educational agency and an institution of higher education, for-profit entity, museum, library, or other entity with relevant expertise. The applicant must submit a detailed project description and an evaluation plan with benchmarks. The Secretary may establish priorities for awarding grants under this part. The Secretary may establish priorities for awards under this part, including innovative models for educational technology, projects serving multiple states, innovative models for underserved populations, and projects with applicant-provided priorities. Priority for projects in education include innovative models for underserved populations like low-income students, students with disabilities, and students with limited English proficiency. Additionally, projects with substantial financial resources, innovative models for challenging courses using electronic networks, and high-speed internet access are also prioritized. "SEC. 3213. USES OF FUNDS." "A recipient must use funds awarded under this part to develop new educational technologies, integrate technology across the curriculum, and carry out activities like improving teachers' ability to integrate technology and developing high-quality digital content." The recipient must use funds to develop high-quality digital content, including multimedia software, digital video, and web-based resources for various subjects and learning environments. This includes new technological formats, computer modeling tools, methods for assessing student performance, distance learning curricula, and digital libraries. The recipient must use funds to develop high-quality digital content, including multimedia software, digital video, web-based resources, and distance learning curricula to support student performance and accessibility for special needs students. Additionally, opportunities for female students to explore various subjects are provided. The recipient must use funds to support students with disabilities, those in remote areas, and limited English proficiency. Activities include using technology for mentoring, providing opportunities for female students in technology, promoting school-family partnerships, acquiring connectivity resources, and collaborating with other technology programs. Acquiring connectivity resources, distance learning networks, hardware, and software as needed for the project goals. Collaborating with other technology research and development programs of the Secretary and the Federal government. The Secretary is authorized to develop tools, provide resources, offer technical assistance, conduct evaluations, and disseminate findings for activities funded under this part. Recipients of funds are limited to using 3 percent for administrative costs. Recipients must also provide a non-federal share of funding. SEC. 3215 limits administrative costs to 3% of funds awarded. SEC. 3216 requires recipients to share in costs, not exceeding 50%. SEC. 3217 authorizes appropriations. Authorized appropriations for fiscal years 2001 and following years. Repeal of former program for National Challenge Grants, with various conforming amendments. The text chunk involves redesignating subsections and headings, as well as making amendments to specific provisions by changing the numbering and removing certain phrases.
